sections.title: The 50/30/20 Budget Rule
sections.content: This simple framework divides your after-tax income into three categories: 50% for needs (housing, food, transportation, utilities), 30% for wants (entertainment, dining out, hobbies), and 20% for savings and debt repayment. It's a flexible starting point that works for most income levels.

points.title: Needs (50%)
points.description: Essential expenses that are difficult to reduce - housing, food, transportation, utilities.

points.title: Wants (30%)
points.description: Discretionary spending - entertainment, dining out, subscriptions, hobbies.

points.title: Savings/Debt (20%)
points.description: Emergency fund, retirement savings, debt repayment, and other financial goals.

sections.title: Track Before You Budget
sections.content: You can't manage what you don't measure. Track your expenses for at least 30 days before creating a budget to understand your actual spending patterns.

sections.title: Identifying Spending Leaks
sections.content: Common spending leaks include unused subscriptions, daily coffee runs, impulse purchases, and convenience fees. Review your bank and credit card statements regularly to identify these leaks and eliminate them.

sections.title: Use Cash for Problem Categories
sections.content: For spending categories you struggle to control, use cash instead of cards. The physical act of handing over money makes spending more conscious and reduces impulse purchases.
